cyrus-imapd-3.4.commit_message: docsrc/conf.py: cyrus-imapd 3.4.6 released
docs: release notes for 3.4.6
github actions: report cyr_buildinfo details
github actions: report cyrus version

github actions: build cass components in parallel

we're running cassandane with four jobs, we might as well run make
with four jobs too

github actions: run cassandane's --slow tests too

Turns out that across a full cassandane run, including the slow tests
doesn't seem to make a noticeable difference to the overall runtime,
at least at present.  So CI might as well just run them every time.

github actions: split cass run into several steps

step 1: build and check all the cassandane components
step 2: run cassandane quietly (-f prettier)
step 3: only if the first cass run failed: rerun with --rerun and
        -f pretty to get noisy output for only the failing tests

Each named step is folded separately in the web interface, so
splitting it like this makes it easier to jump to the detail you
care about, without having to scroll through all the output for
the entire cassandane run.

Re-running the failed tests and only failing the workflow if
there's still failures might also reduce false negatives from
transient test failures, which are almost never related to the PR
being evaluated anyway.

github actions: set safe.directory for build directory

actions/checkout@v3 does this temporarily for itself, but removes
it when it's done.

Even though we're no longer fetching the tags manually, we still need git
commands to work (in particular, tools/git-version.sh used by the build
needs "git describe" to set the version string), so we need to set
safe.directory manually for that.

While we're here, log the result of tools/git-version.sh so if something
is gonna break due to a weird version, the autopsy has that information
up front.
github actions: add 3.8 to CI

github actions: let actions/checkout@v3 do the full fetch

rather than configuring it for a basic fetch and then tinkering
with it after the fact

github actions: use 'shell: bash' for multiline runs

This allegedly also turns on bash's fast-fail 'set -eo pipefail'
behaviour, such that a failure from any line fails the whole step.

github actions: get tags from upstream

cyrus version detection is based on release tags, which most forks
probably don't have, and shouldn't need to

cassandane dockertests config: skip some known-bad tests

They are only known bad on our current, slightly out of date Docker
image.  We will fix the image, then fix this.

Signed-off-by: Ricardo Signes <rjbs@semiotic.systems>

github actions: Grab all syslog messages from cassandane test runs

This makes figuring out test failures easier as we'll know what
Cyrus complained about.

Unfortunately, this makes the log file extremely large.

In the future, maybe we can find a way to only grab the syslog
files of failing tests...

tools/build-with-cyruslibs.sh - Also build JMAP support!

Otherwise cassandane can't test any of the JMAP functionality.

github actions: Don't run cassandane Core tests

There may be a way to get these to work, but I don't currently see it.

I *think* we need to change fs.suid_dumpable but that's not something we
can change in the docker container as far as I know.

For now, let's just skip them.

github actions: Install missing dependencies cassandane needs

These aren't in the docker image apparently. This gets things working

github actions: We need a full repo and tags to get cyrus version

Without the tags (and a full depth repo), tools/git-version.sh would return
"unknown", so any tests based on cyrus version would see "0.0.0" instead of
"3.7.0".

github actions: Run docker with init as process id 1

When cassandane starts up daemons, they double fork and the middle parent
exits. This causes the daemons to be raparented to pid 1.

That means we can't use `waitpid` or `wait` to clean up zombies, pid 1 must
clean them up.

Github sets up `tail -f /dev/null` as process id 1, and any zombie children
don't get automatically reaped.

 `stop_command()` and `_stop_pid()` would end up waiting a full 60 seconds
trying to end the processes, and then fail, claiming they were still
running (because they were -- as zombies!)

With `docker run --init`, we get a proper init daemon that reaps zombies,
and tests pass in a timely manner (10m instead of 3.5h!)

ci: Remove travis config

Switch to using Github Actions instead.

Signed-off-by: Partha Susarla <mail@spartha.org>

ci: add github workflow

cyrus-imapd has been relying on Travis CI for builds. And Travis CI
has been pretty unreliable for our use-case as we keep running out of
'free OSS credits'.
This commit adds support for Github Actions for builds.

While most of what we did with Travis worked with Actions, a minor
change in the how cassandane stops processes was also needed and is a
part of this commit. The change was to use `stop_command()` method
instead of `_stop_pid()` method directly, making sure that a
`waitpid()` call is made after a `kill()`.

Signed-off-by: Partha Susarla <mail@spartha.org>

Fixes #4574

Thanks to @dilyanpalauzov

confusing consequences, when the computer could just do it whenever

docsrc/conf.py: cyrus-imapd 3.6.3 and 3.8.1 released

sitemap.py: sort work list for a stable sitemap.xml

The default ordering of env.found_docs seems to be unstable in newer
Sphinx versions, resulting in sitemap.xml changes every single time
the website builder runs, even if nothing actually changed.

With this list now processed in sorted order, sitemap.xml shouldn't
change unless we've actually added, removed, or renamed documents.
docs: remove unused sphinx extensions

doc generation: stop using custom manpage builder

Why is the current one broken with newer libraries?

I don't know!  But we also no longer know why we had a custom builder,
either.  At first glance, the output without the custom code seems fine.
We should inspect it more, and then we can decide if we can go forward
with this and also delete the custom code!
RunnerPretty: colour the summary output too

docs: remove post-upgrade survey link

we're not doing anything useful with the responses anyway
docs: 3.8.0 released
docsrc/conf.py: release 3.6.1, 3.4.5, 3.2.11, 3.0.18
docs: release notes for 3.4.5
docs: release notes for 3.2.11
docs: release notes for 3.0.18
rfc822_header.c: now using gperf 3.1

backend: improve backend_version() robustness

* don't choke on capabilities-in-banner-response
* don't choke on pre-release version decorators
backend.testc: test backend_version with pre-release version strings
backend.testc: test backend_version with both capabilities styles

backend: forward-safe backend_version()

If the backend's banner version looks sensible, but is larger than
anything we know about, infer that it supports at least the same
MAILBOX_MINOR_VERSION that this server does.

This fixes forever the problem where XFER would lose data when
sending mailboxes to a backend newer than it recognised; and removes
the need to update backend_version(), backport it, and do releases
from all the older branches, every time a new Cyrus version is created.

backend_version() still needs to be updated appropriately any time
MAILBOX_MINOR_VERSION changes, but only when it changes.

This also simplifies handling of banner versions from 3.0 forward.
Sieve: test_notify() works as far back as 3.2

RunnerPretty: show test status on left, not right

This makes the output more readable when viewed on something that's
not an 80-char wide fixed-width terminal, without compromising
readability on a terminal
bc_eval.c: do case-insensitive URI comparisons
bc_eval.c: enotify method is a URI

tools/compile_st.pl: strip 'Command-line' from gperf output

We version control the output file from this command, and having
the name of the tempfile used to generate it embedded in the output
made it show up as different every time it was regenerated, even
though usually the only difference was the name of the tempfile.

Now it will only show up as different when something interesting
changed.

Fixes #4247

Cassini: don't choke on repeated params

Fixes a bug where if a param in the [config] section was specified
more than once, we'd produce junk imapd.conf files, and then all
tests would error out due to master aborting.

This used to be required for Cassandane to run properly, but
hasn't been required for a while.

Signed-off-by: Christian Walther <walther@indel.ch>

JMAPCalendars: fix calendarevent-get-locations-geo match

Makes the test less sensitive to the number of decimal positions
returned by libical, which can vary between versions

Also includes a data update from 14126c4eaf54248a458e9d0c0c18e97ffdde5761

configure: search for GitPython with Python 2 and 3

Debian 11 (bullseye) is now shipping the Python 3 versions of Sphinx and
GitPython, which aren't detected using the "default" python. This looks
for it under both names.

All this is doing is deciding if the package is available so that
sphinx-build can actually work, so there's no further work required to
link it in or anything.

The downside here is that if the sphinx-build on PATH is the Python 2
version and GitPython is Python 3 (or vice-versa), this could still end
up with the configure "succeeding" and then sphinx-build failing later.
A better test for all of this would be to test sphinx-build with a
minimal document that requires the wanted modules explicitly, and see if
that succeeds (exactly like what the AC_CHECK_ macros do by generating
and compiling a small C program). That's a bunch more work right now for
a situation that isn't likely to happen (you're likely to be all-in on
one complete version of Python or the other), so I'm punting on that.

sieveshell: fix segfault after quit

Exit after processing the 'quit' command, otherwise further commands
will segfault because sieve_logout() invalidates the object.

Broken in 4f3d911, see also https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=962362

Co-authored-by: Valentin Vidic <vvidic@debian.org>
